The person who can "eat anything", Michel Lotito, couldn't eat soft foods such as bananas and hard-boiled eggs, it made him physically sick. Michel Lotito died at age 57, which is 22 years younger than the average French male. Embryo selection seems like a given to remove known bad genes from the gene pool, until genetic editing becomes more reliable and then we could strengthen existing traits and add new traits. Looking at the bacteria Deinococcus radiodurans, we could one day make ourselves resistant to cold, radiation, acid, dehydration, even the vacuum of space. Looking at other members of the Deinococcales family, they have resistance to heat, which would be very helpful for growing crops in the desert. Some scientists have proposed that life on Earth may have been seeded by some of these bacteria, the theory known as panspermia, as they have been proven to be able to live on the outside of the International Space Station.

I hate to tell you this, but this is overly optimistic and doesn't follow historical patterns (and some most of this is just fantasy-novel bogus altogether). Human technology goes through phases. For example, ancient people 2000 years ago in Greece had things like sidewalks, traffic, plumbing (which allowed them to make their own version of internal heating and even early flushing toilets), theatrical special effects, and even geared machinery. However, in spite of all that technology, they still fell and the technology was lost--some of it forever. Mankind had to start over. This has happened in every society where technology advances (to include ancient Egypt and ancient Rome). The people either A) disappear off the face of the planet; B) are conquered by an oppressive government and all technology stops and regresses; or C) their world is destroyed and they are scattered to the winds and/or have to rebuild from scratch elsewhere without the knowledge of how their technology was created in order to reproduce it. It's sad that some of these technologies are so advanced that modern scientists can't figure out how they were created, and some go as far to insult the intelligence of the past by saying that it must have been "aliens."

One of two things usually happens to create this. Sometimes, like with the people of Pompeii or those who were struck by debilitating disease, nature strikes and wipes them out--or nearly completely. Other times you see that as technology grows, corruption, loose morals, and wasteful living grow alongside it, thus opening them up for conflict whether with rivaling political ideologies internally or by lowering their defenses against outside forces that use the opportunity to attack.

Today, everyday people who use these technologies call themselves "advanced" when the average person is actually pretty uneducated and knows nothing about how it works or how to recreate it. They're taking credit for someone else's genius. How many people do you know can create their own computer from scratch at home? You can probably think of a couple, but here's another question--can they make all the parts themselves? If the supply, demand, and resources for them has ceased, they may find it nearly impossible. Mass production would be out of the question. That's assuming you still even have power anymore, depending on how bad the regression is. Lack of knowledge and resources is the problem many ancient people faced when rebuilding.

Think it can't happen today? One half of Korea is extremely advanced. In the other half of Korea, most civilians don't even have power and could executed for killing a draft animal to eat. That's just the difference in politics. Here's a better example: Iran was an up-and-coming country only about 40 years ago (Google 1970s Iran). In less than 20 years, they lost it all and regressed centuries in one fell swoop. Only a few remnants of a different era lingered behind in the aftermath.

Even today, look at the people who are using the technology. Just like in ancient days, emphasis on comfort and wasteful lifestyles are already on the rise in "developed" nations. People are becoming aggressive towards their OWN citizens, they're becoming selfish and narcissistic, and make major life choices on how easy or convenient to their everyday lifestyle something is. They let raw emotion and impulse guide their immediate words and actions without thought of consequences or respect of authority. That is the perfect foundation for man-made tragedy mentioned above--and if that wasn't bad enough, the United States sits on a mega volcano that probably won't stay sleeping for another 1000 years. If that volcano goes off, there will certainly be survivors--but it will destroy the nation and affect many others. The world market would be destroyed in an instant. Just like before, people would have to go into survivor mode and do what they can to pick up the pieces--and there will be technological losses.

History goes up and down. We're on the up swing of technology right now. We're probably heading for a down swing. You're more likely to see that in 1000 years, technology is more like a strange mix of current or alternative technology (new technology that replaces the roll of previous ones), a couple minor new technologies, and some that we would consider archaic technology by today's standards. (Think steampunk, but not not necessarily steam technology or Victorian style clothes, but rather a mixture of eras).

Edical experts, historians and archaeologists have examined in detail the execution that Jesus Christ voluntarily endured. All agree that he suffered one of the most gruelling and painful forms of capital punishment ever devised by man. Here is a brief summary of some of the things we know about his last hours from history, archaeology and medicine…

Severe stress, even before the abuse began
Jesus had the weight of the world on his shoulders. Even before the crucifixion began, he clearly had physical symptoms associated with severe stress. The night before the execution, his disciples reported seeing Jesus in “agony” on the Mount of Olives. Not only did he not sleep all night, but he seems to have been sweating profusely. So great was the stress that tiny blood vessels were rupturing in his sweat glands and emitting as great red drops that fell to the ground (see Luke 22:44). This symptom of severe stress is called hematohidrosis.
Jesus was physically exhausted and in danger of going into shock unless he received fluids (which he apparently did not). This is the man that the Roman soldiers tortured.

Torture by beating with Roman scourges
Having previously been beaten by the Jews, it was now the Romans’ turn. The beatings administered by Roman soldiers are well known to be very bloody, leaving lacerations all over the body. Romans designed their whips to cut the flesh from their victim’s bodies. These beatings were designed to be painful to the extreme. It would also cause a fluid build up around his lungs. In addition, a crown of thorns was forced into his scalp which was capable of severely irritating major nerves in his head, causing increasing and excruciating pain, as the hours wore on.
In Christ’s severely stressed condition, these beatings were easily enough to kill him. His body was horribly bruised, cut and bleeding. Having had no nourishment for many hours, and having lost fluids through profuse sweating and much bleeding, Jesus would have been severely dehydrated. This brutal torture would certainly be sending him into what doctors call “shock,” and shock kills.
In addition, Jesus was forced to carry the the wooden beam on which he would die. Imagine the effect of carrying a heavy weight if you were in that condition.

Crucifixion
Hung completely naked before the crowd, the pain and damage caused by crucifixion were designed to be so devilishly intense that one would continually long for death, but could linger for days with no relief.
According to Dr. Frederick Zugibe, piercing of the median nerve of the hands with a nail can cause pain so incredible that even morphine won’t help, “severe, excruciating, burning pain, like lightning bolts traversing the arm into the spinal cord.” Rupturing the foot’s plantar nerve with a nail would have a similarly horrible effect.
Furthermore, the position of the body on a cross is designed to make it extremely difficult to breathe.
Frederick Farrar described the intended, torturous effect: “For indeed a death by crucifixion seems to include all that pain and death can have of horrible and ghastly—dizziness, cramp, thirst, starvation, sleeplessness, traumatic fever, tetanus, shame, publicity of shame, long continuance of torment, horror of anticipation, mortification of untended wounds—all intensified just up to the point at which they can be endured at all, but all stopping just short of the point which would give to the suffer the relief of unconsciousness.”
One doctor has called it “a symphony of pain” produced by every movement, with every breath; even a slight breeze on his skin could bring screaming pain at this point.
Medical examiner, Dr. Frederick Zugibe, believes Christ died from shock due to loss of blood and fluid, plus traumatic shock from his injuries, plus cardiogenic shock causing Christ’s heart to fail.

At the ninth hour (the time at which a sacrificial lamb was killed everyday in the Jewish temple), Jesus cried out with a loud voice, saying, “Eloi, Eloi, lama sabachthani?” which is translated,“My God, My God, why have You forsaken Me?” and soon died, after saying “It is finished.” At about this moment is probably the time when the temple’s priestly ram’s horn would have been blown that day, announcing that the priests had completed the sacrifice of the lamb for the sins of Israel. Also at that moment, the great, thick curtain that closed the Holy of Holies room from view, ripped open from top to bottom. —Mark 15:34 and Matthew 27:46

James Thompson believed that Jesus did not die from exhaustion, the beatings or the 3 hours of crucifixion, but that he died from agony of mind producing rupture of the heart. His evidence comes from what happened when the Roman soldier pierced Christ’s left side. The spear released a sudden flow of blood and water (John 19:34). Not only does this prove that Jesus was already dead when pierced, but Thompson believes it is also evidence of cardiac rupture. Respected physiologist Samuel Houghton believed that only the combination of crucifixion and rupture of the heart could produce this result.
There is no question that it was painful beyond words.
Biblically, it is clear that Jesus chose and willed His moment of death. That moment was induced not by pain, emotional stress, heart attack, or any other, but by His will. Though fully human, He is also fully divine. As God, He could not die from external sources, but only of His own volition and will.
Near the end, a criminal beside him mocked, “If you are the Christ, save yourself and us.” Little did this sinner know that the man he was speaking to hung there voluntarily. He was speaking to our Creator, capable of releasing all the power in the universe and beyond, and easily saving himself. Jesus remained in this agony and shame, not because he was powerless, but because of his incredible love for humanity. He suffered to provide the needed way of salvation for you and me.

In 1000 years, we might not even have futuristic technology. If our population never grows, we could keep dropping. Our education could drop to. This could spread over to other places around the world. Places could go into a crisis due to other continents not being able to send oil, food etc. over. The currency would probably change to if we could no longer get a hold of it. We'd live in a somewhat apocalyptic world without zombies or mutated humans but with humans going through a depression of trying to live without things that they need.

(This is only a thought, this could happen, maybe not, who knows.)

Both humans and everything else in the biosphere gathers harmful mutations at an alarming rate with each new generation. These harmful mutations will cause more and more diseases within each species and make them less able to survive. More extinctions will occur. Many lifeforms depend on other lifeforms for their survival, so when some essential life forms (like bees) go extinct, a bunch of dependent lifeforms will die out along with them.

There is no rosy future for humanity. No colonising other planets, because those who colonise them will go there with a vast mutational load (increased by cosmic radiation experienced during the journey there) and will not have any better chance at surviving on another planet as they do here. Extinction due to excessive genetic mutations will eventually catch up with them too and wipe them out.

Sorry to rain on everyone's parade, but this is the reality we face.

If your really think about it, It is crazy what humanity has come to! If you show a smartphone from today to a person that lived 100 years ago, they would call it magic. Technology is so incredible, that we already think of space colonies and spaceships that take us to other stars. We can cut metall with laser beams. We can send informations to the other side of the earth and it barely takes a second. 300 years ago it took months or even years to send letters to other countries, let alone continents. Often the messages never reached their destination. We understand almost anything in nature. We can tell how far stars are away from earth by just looking through a giant telescope that we assembled in space. We can fly to places in the world within 15 hours, where 100 years ago it took years to get to. We can predict the weather. We can tell how old a lake is, by digging in its ground, looking for leaves that fell into the lake many years ago. A cellphone from today has more calculating power than the NASA during Apollo 7 (Moonlanding).
50 years ago, 4 Megabyte storage capacity weighted around 20 tons. Today there are storage cards that weight around 4 gramm and their capacity is 512 Gigabyte. Thats around 128000 times more.
The average lifespan of a human during the black death was 30 years. Today the average lifespan in e.g. Germany is 82 years.

Just thinking about the progress that is happening right now all over the world blows my mind!

Except this is a fantastical version of the future that won't exist without major policy change and scientific breakthroughs.

The World is projected to run out of fossil fuels in 300 years. That is oil, coal, and natural gas. And most rare metals are running out as well. Unless we get some major scientific breakthrough we will be back to the pre-industrial society we were 200 years ago. Most technology requires fossil fuels for components. We can not build solar energy without fossil fuels and computers require rare metals. Any hope of these fantastic advancements die in the next 300 years, without solving these problems. At our current level of options industrialized society is doomed.

On the climate topic; CO2 levels will have dropped back down in 1000 years to pre-industry levels. So global warming is not a long term concern. We run out of fossil fuels and the problem solves itself. Your speculation on global temp rising is way off. The majority of the next 1000 years is a society without fossil fuels. CO2 will be naturally dissipating for the majority of it. And in 2000 years the conditions that coincide with the return of the cyclical Ice Ages we are between begin.

So please get your facts right. In 1000 years we will probably be living in colonial style houses, burning wood, trying to stave off our extinction in the upcoming ice age.

This video is interesting, but in reality, it is impossible to predict the future.  This video shows a positive prediction of the future, but literally anything can happen.  It is important to know this because NOTHING is certain.  Humans believe they are living on a globe in space because that is what science has proven, but as far as we know, the Milky Way can be a piece of bacteria in a whole new world.  There are actually an infinite amount of possibilities of why life exists and what our place is in the universe.  SO, what I am trying to say is: keep an open mind and never think things are written in stone.  If you make a mistake, always keep in mind that there are infinite ways of correcting it and infinite possibilities that branch off in many directions past it.  I hope I offered some good advice, and it would be nice to see this thought shared with other people.  :D

I think it's important to note that many of the evolutionary changes mentioned can only happen if these changes become necessary for survival. Meaning that those without say, darker skin, will die as a result of their lack of protection from UV radiation BEFORE they have the chance to reproduce and pass on those genes. Beneficial mutations rarely hold if they don't give the creature a better chance of surviving, which means that it must have a higher survival rate than its predecessor. Again, that means that those without the mutations have to be less likely to survive, and unable to reproduce before death. The only way evolution can work on a large scale, like with 7-15 billion people, is if the species that lacks the mutation that protects them from any given danger, begins to go extinct, giving way for the new, genetically well adapted species to take hold. Rarely does a new species rise from mere chance if it's predecessor can survive equally as well as the successor.

Even in case you could move all your conscious and un-conscious thoughts and memories into any computer, there's no way to transfer your particular ability - or lack of ability - to relate them. So the resulting "brain" will never act like you nor have YOUR awareness of a sudden time, circumstances and place.
We are not a sum of memories or experiences, we can tell or transmit them: but the one who gets that information can never perceive the same as us, neither relate ideas in the same way.
For example: a computer don't need to hurry, and that's a critical factor for our behaviour.
In addition, the mere fact that the computer does not discard options or memories like you do turns the resulting brain into something completely different.

We gave up on our right to be part of the natural cycle of life, or should i say "the law of the jungle". its true that the lion eat the gazelle. however only the strongest get to eat, and only weakest get to be eaten. For us, this law is called "anarchism", "exploitation", "discrimination" and a bunch of other "unethical" terms. I am not saying we are wrong, but the ethics are something humans made to defy nature's laws of life and death, alongside with technology. think of it, ethics are so different from a population to an other, yet nature always stays the same everywhere.
again, im not saying this is bad, humanity rose against the laws we and all those before us were ment to fall under, and we crafted a new world where the strongest are restrained and the weakest are protected (or is it?) but with playing gods, we are now on our own, rather we force nature to go by our own made rules, or we fall under its reign once more.

This is terrifying. Death is a part of LIFE. Without death we wouldn't know what it's like to LIVE. And I would never, EVER, put 'nano-bots' into my body. Imagine, children of the future never knowing what it is like to weep as your mother puts a bandage on your bloodied knee. Not knowing what it is like to stay home from school, bedridden, and sick. Coughing, and sobbing as your mother lays a cool cloth on your skin, burning with fever. No tears, and numb grief when a loved one passes away, for death has been concurred. No crying on your bed, because you're 'too fat' or 'too ugly' for society's standards. No growing old and marrying the man/woman you are in love with, because aging is a thing of the past. No laughing hysterically when your friend hurts themselves. No watching your child grow up, and fall in love. No long car rides, bored out of your mind, because no one uses cars. No walking home in the rain. No snowball fights. No getting in trouble at school. No childhood. No LIFE. Is that happiness? Is that life? Sure, life can be hard, but that's what makes it worth LIVING! The adventures, the laughs, the tears, the love, gone. I don't know if that is living to you, but it certainly isn't to me. A computer can't feel. Only a living thing can.

Albeit cartoonish and a super safe explanation of an undeniably disturbing dystopian future of nano-machines inside our bodies, I personally don't think it matters or is even realistic to believe our descendants will even get to enjoy the 2200's let alone how great and amazing humans will be in a thousand years, because all those beautiful cities will be at the bottom of the sea or filled with smog. We love to romanticize about the future, but always seem to leave out climate change and it's inevitable effect it will create. Because of our enormous economic footprint, there may not be a future for most living creatures. We enjoy the notion that we'll come to our senses and become energy efficient and truly care about the impact we've given to the environment.

Overly-developed cultures developed a bad behavior in the last 10,000 years of hoarding resources and most societies are far too wrapped in their own ego to change or consider an alternative to existing. Even if we stopped and went green tomorrow, the environment would still be affected and will need several decades to heal. Fossil fuel emissions, animal agriculture, methane emissions, and land consumption, shit we humans are doing - is destroying ecosystems. For life to flourish as it is now, humanity must slow down. Respect nature, and not be in such a rush to evolve and expand consciousness. Humankind is eager to become God, know everything, and live forever. That's all this culture is really interested in.

If things keep on going, business as usual, humanity will lose everything in a thousand years. Nothing lasts forever, even the sun has an expiration date. Civilizations like Rome or Mesopotamia rose and fell slowly and we've learned only how to conquer better. Civilizations today will fall much faster and we'll have to learn and teach all over again. Galaxies and stars are like ghosts, depending on your vantage point in universe, we could already be dead.

In the case of evolution, in order for us to react to environmental changes, population must be filtered by natural selection. People need to die at enormous amounts in order for natural selection to actually work based on environmental factors. And they don't. And that's a good thing. Meaning that the only reason why light skin might disappear is because of globalization and interracial couples.
The only natural selection we have right now is based on not survival, but reproduction. Whose genes are actually selected for reproduction. Usually it's the genes of the uneducated, or religious zealots that oppose reproductive freedoms even at the level of using basic measures of contraception. If there is any genetic traits that contribute to such traits, it's those genes that are naturally selected today.

Consider the Powers of Two and the fact that world population has more than doubled in just 67 years -- from 2.5B when I was born to over 7B today. Then extrapolate at that same exponential rate. In another lifetime population may double again to about 18B, especially as we work to cure aging. In 500 years population could reach a trillion. Will Earth be able to support that? How will people eat. Where will they live? Will they have meaningful employment as machines replace most human functions? Will we somehow work to limit population growth? Who decides that? Or will it be decided for us through nature or as an unforeseen result of our own actions? What life survives when humans die off?

The world's rising temperature and the deterioration of the ozone hole are independent. Models predict that the ozone layer will recover to its normal (pre-1980's) values by 2050-2070. If the emissions of ozone depleting substances were not regulated according to the Montreal protocol and its amendments, we wouldn't have had to wait a 1000 years for evolution to take its course. Within less than a 100 years we would be already extinct from skin cancer and deterioration of all the rest of life on the planet.
On a side note, since ozone is a green house gas, the deterioration of the ozone layer leads to a decrease in stratospheric temperatures.

While it's true that height has increased by 10 cm since the industrial revolution, it was the industrial revolution that caused the short height in the first place (from sickness, lack of good nutrition, poverty, etc.).

The Medieval period has a very bad rap historically, but if you look at nutrition, people actually did quite well -- and that shows in height from that period. People were only an inch or so shorter than we are today, and the difference in that inch or is due to things like sickness. You see the same thing if you compare Europe during the 1700 and 1800s to the US, which was more agrarian and had better health -- our height today is in the US is only an inch or two taller than our 'founding fathers.'

In reality, when factoring for nutrition and poverty, human height is basically the same today as its always been, and it's not likely to change going into the future short of direct genetic manipulation.

You want a picture of the future, here it is: the world is covered in a vast "sea" of utility fog. Humans are sprinkled throughout, living as uploaded brains in virtual worlds being simulated by the fog around them. If they wish to leave the virtual world, they can easily and the fog forms a physical human avatar for them. This avatar can form anywhere in the world, not just where they actually "are", making global travel trivial. And in the virtual world, absolutely anything can be simulated. Food, clothing, housing, whatever. As you are naturally indestructible in the virtual world, many of the "needs" we current have are no longer present. In the real world, your only needs are electrical power and access to the utility fog, both are produced in enormous abundance by robotic labor, and are free for all. Biological humans still exist, but they are either those who for whatever reason refuse to get uploaded (no one is forced to, of course), and children who are too young (there's an age limit to getting uploaded). Children are conceived and born from artificial wombs, from synthesized DNA strands built to be genetically identical to those their parents once had.

That will have limited speed at which it can be moved. The only alternative would be to have an embodiment at the source and destination, but there's the other catch. If our entire existence were encapsulated in data in a computer the sheer volume of that data would mean that it might take between days and years to move it from point A to point B and that would be nearly the same whether it was across the room or across the world. This video makes the all to common assumption that how natural selection has worked in the past is how it will work with humanity going forward.

Natural selection is driven by the basic premise that, over long-periods of time, individuals with a particular advantageous gene will have a reproductive advantage over those without the gene. Normally, the mechanism for this is that individuals with the advantageous are more likely to reach reproductive age/be attractive to mates.

That is no longer the case in most modern societies. How many children a particular human has is far more likely to be influenced by their upbringing, socio-economic status, religion...etc than it is by whether they have any advantageous genes. Very few humans die before reaching reproductive age any more, even in most developing societies. And being attractive doesn't necessarily correlate to having more children.

The types of things that do correlate to having more or less children, such as ethnicity in some cases, are very transient. An ethnicity with a relatively high birth rate today may have a low birth rate in 500 years, which is nothing in evolutionary terms.

And no. More mix-raced babies...etc is not evolution, its just intermixing.

Looking 1000 years into the future is impossible, given the changes we will see just in the next 100 years. Our descendants 100 years from now (assuming we survive that long) will be more digital than organic, and will spend most of their time in a virtual world rather than the physical one (possibilities in a virtual world are limitless). By 100 years after that, organic humans may be gone entirely, with intelligence being entirely digital. When we have immortality and physical needs are no longer an issue, human existence will be so different that we organic mortals cannot comprehend it now. And that's only after 200 years - the next 800 years beyond that may involve digital merging with one or more alien species, in which case, it is not physically possible for us to comprehend the vastly expanded "society" our descendants will live in.
